That's exactly where my CUDA runtime libs: /is/software/nvidia/cuda-8.0/lib64 .
Just in case it helps, I added a few ls commands from my CUDA directory at the end of the GitHub gist, so you can see its architecture. Apart from separating the CUDA and CUDNN libraries, this architecture seems quite in line with what the pytorch/tools/setup_files/{cuda.py,cudnn.py} expect.
So just to be sure: when you say

It seems that you don't have it in the default paths.

you don't mean that I should add cuda-8.0/lib64 directory to my PATH environment variable, but just that this architecture with separate cuda and cudnn directories is a bit unusual, right?

body:
That's exactly where my CUDA runtime libs: `/is/software/nvidia/cuda-8.0/lib64` .
Just in case it helps, I added a few `ls` commands from my CUDA directory at the end of the GitHub gist, so you can see its architecture. Apart from separating the CUDA and CUDNN libraries, this architecture seems quite in line with what the pytorch/tools/setup_files/{cuda.py,cudnn.py} expect.
So just to be sure: when you say

> It seems that you don't have it in the default paths.

you don't mean that I should add cuda-8.0/lib64 directory to my PATH environment variable, but just that this architecture with separate cuda and cudnn directories is a bit unusual, right?
